1â†’# Phase 44: Quality Report Fix & Traceability Cleanup - Research
     2â†’
     3â†’**Researched:** 2026-02-18
     4â†’**Domain:** Python bug fix, pytest unit testing, YAML config, asyncio parallelization
     5â†’**Confidence:** HIGH
     6â†’
     7â†’<user_constraints>
     8â†’## User Constraints (from CONTEXT.md)
     9â†’
    10â†’### Locked Decisions
    11â†’
    12â†’- **No Playwright Tests**: Playwright tests are removed from Phase 44 scope entirely. Phase 43 UI verification will be done through other means (manual or future phase).
    13â†’- **E2E Issue Triage**: Already-fixed issues (#1, #2, #3, #10) are out of scope. In-scope: Issues #4 (orphan traces â€” startup cleanup), #5 (consent extraction), #6 ('Other' routing), #7 (grounding parallelization), #9 (RxNorm docs), #11 (sentence extraction test), #12 (circuit breaker test). Issue #8 (MLflow ContextVar async boundary) is documentation-only.
    14â†’- **Issue #6: 'Other' routing**: Add explicit `Other: []` entry in routing.yaml with a comment â€” config-driven, no code change in TerminologyRouter.
    15â†’- **Grounding Parallelization (Issue #7)**: DO NOT DEFER. Implement in this phase. Concurrency: 4 via asyncio.gather with semaphore. Both ToolUniverse lookups AND MedGemma calls concurrent. Batching: 4 entities per MedGemma prompt, batches run concurrently. Error isolation: failed entity gets expert_review routing. Per-entity timing logs. Tenacity retry within parallel grounding.
    16â†’- **Orphan Trace Cleanup (Issue #4)**: Automated startup cleanup â€” on service start, find IN_PROGRESS traces older than 1 hour and close as ERROR.
    17â†’
    18â†’### Claude's Discretion
    19â†’
    20â†’- Whether tenacity retries hold the semaphore slot or release/reacquire (implementation complexity tradeoff)
    21â†’- Exact placement of orphan trace cleanup (trigger.py startup or Docker entrypoint)
    22â†’- MLflow ContextVar documentation format and placement (Issue #8)
    23â†’- MedGemma batch prompt structure for multi-entity calls
    24â†’
    25â†’### Deferred Ideas (OUT OF SCOPE)
    26â†’
    27â†’None â€” discussion stayed within phase scope
    28â†’</user_constraints>
    29â†’
    30â†’<phase_requirements>
    31â†’## Phase Requirements
    32â†’
    33â†’| ID | Description | Research Support |
    34â†’|----|-------------|-----------------|
    35â†’| QUAL-07 | Report includes LLM heuristic assessment of extraction completeness and grounding accuracy | Bug confirmed at line 653: `criterion.get("criteria_text", "")` â€” field is `"text"` in ExtractedCriterion schema and API response |
    36â†’| BUG-01 | Report catalogs ungrounded entities (entities with no CUI and no terminology codes) | Bug confirmed at line 391: `criterion.get("criteria_text")` â€” same field name mismatch |
    37â†’| BUG-03 | Report catalogs structural issues (criteria without entities, entities without criteria) | Bug confirmed at line 460: `criterion.get("criteria_text")` â€” same field name mismatch |
    38â†’| FIX-B6 | Protocol list deduplicates re-uploaded protocols | Already implemented in Phase 43 per REQUIREMENTS.md (listed as Pending â€” traceability update needed) |
    39â†’| FIX-B8 | Dead Letter protocols have Retry and Archive action buttons | Already implemented in Phase 43 per REQUIREMENTS.md (listed as Pending â€” traceability update needed) |
    40â†’| CLEAN-01 | Legacy v1 services deleted | Already Complete in Phase 40 â€” confirmed in REQUIREMENTS.md traceability table |
    41â†’| CLEAN-02 | ToolUniverse SDK replaces UmlsClient | Already Complete in Phase 40 â€” confirmed in REQUIREMENTS.md traceability table |
    42â†’| CLEAN-03 | Zero imports from deleted legacy services | Already Complete in Phase 40 â€” confirmed in REQUIREMENTS.md traceability table |
    43â†’| CLEAN-04 | Pipeline produces grounded entities with >0% CUI rate | Already Complete in Phase 40 â€” confirmed in REQUIREMENTS.md traceability table |
    44â†’| CLEAN-05 | MedGemma agentic reasoning loop with 3-question retry and expert_review routing | Already Complete in Phase 40 â€” confirmed in REQUIREMENTS.md traceability table |
    45â†’</phase_requirements>
    46â†’
    47â†’## Summary
    48â†’
    49â†’Phase 44 is primarily a bug-fix and cleanup phase with one significant new feature (grounding parallelization). The codebase is well-understood â€” all the files to be modified have been read and their current state is confirmed.
    50â†’
    51â†’The most critical fix is the `criteria_text` field name bug in `scripts/quality_eval.py`. The API response schema (`ExtractedCriterion`) uses field name `"text"` for the criterion text, but quality_eval.py uses `"criteria_text"` in three locations (lines 391, 460, 653), causing all three quality report sections (ungrounded entities catalog, structural issues catalog, and LLM assessment sample criteria) to show empty strings instead of real criterion text. This is confirmed by reading both the schema and quality_eval.py.
    52â†’
    53â†’The grounding parallelization (Issue #7) is the highest-complexity change: converting the sequential `for` loop in `ground_node` to use `asyncio.gather` with a semaphore. The existing architecture in `ground.py` is a single async function with a sequential loop â€” this is ready to be parallelized without any structural changes needed beyond the loop itself. The MedGemma batching decision is for Claude's discretion â€” the existing `medgemma_decider.py` calls one entity at a time, and the batch prompt structure needs to be defined.
    54â†’
    55â†’CLEAN-01 through CLEAN-05 are already confirmed Complete in REQUIREMENTS.md with Phase 40 assignment, so the traceability verification task is purely a read-and-confirm step (the plan only needs to mark FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 as Complete for Phase 43, since those were implemented in Phase 43 per the dashboard UX work).
    56â†’
    57â†’**Primary recommendation:** Fix the `criteria_text` â†’ `text` rename first (lowest risk, highest value), then add the `Other: []` YAML entry and consent prompt instruction, then implement the unit tests, then tackle grounding parallelization last (highest complexity, most testing needed).
    58â†’
    59â†’## Standard Stack
    60â†’
    61â†’### Core
    62â†’
    63â†’| Library | Version | Purpose | Why Standard |
    64â†’|---------|---------|---------|--------------|
    65â†’| asyncio | stdlib | Concurrency for grounding parallelization | Already used throughout codebase â€” trigger.py uses asyncio.run(), ground_node is async |
    66â†’| pybreaker | >=1.2.0 | Circuit breaker for tu_breaker, gemini_breaker | Already in shared/resilience.py and used in tooluniverse_client.py |
    67â†’| tenacity | >=8.2.0 | Retry logic in _call_tool_with_resilience and TerminologyRouter | Already wired up in both files |
    68â†’| pyyaml | >=6.0 | YAML config load for routing.yaml | Already used in TerminologyRouter.__init__ |
    69â†’| pytest | >=8.0.0 | Test framework for new unit tests | Already used in tests/test_terminology_router.py |
    70â†’| mlflow | >=3.8.1 | MLflow client for orphan trace cleanup | Already imported in trigger.py |
    71â†’
    72â†’### Supporting
    73â†’
    74â†’| Library | Version | Purpose | When to Use |
    75â†’|---------|---------|---------|-------------|
    76â†’| pytest-asyncio | >=0.23.0 | Async test support | For any test that needs to await â€” check if sentence extraction tests need it |
    77â†’| jinja2 | >=3.1.0 | Prompt templates | For modifying system.jinja2 extraction prompt |
    78â†’
    79â†’### Alternatives Considered
    80â†’
    81â†’| Instead of | Could Use | Tradeoff |
    82â†’|------------|-----------|----------|
    83â†’| asyncio.Semaphore for concurrency cap | asyncio.BoundedSemaphore | BoundedSemaphore raises on over-release â€” safer but overkill for controlled code |
    84â†’| asyncio.gather for parallelization | asyncio.TaskGroup (Python 3.11+) | TaskGroup cancels all tasks on first error â€” we want error isolation, so gather with return_exceptions=True is better |
    85â†’
    86â†’## Architecture Patterns
    87â†’
    88â†’### Recommended Project Structure
    89â†’
    90â†’No new directories needed. All changes are within existing files or adding new test files in existing test directories.
    91â†’
    92â†’```
    93â†’scripts/
    94â†’â””â”€â”€ quality_eval.py            # Fix criteria_text -> text at lines 391, 460, 653
    95â†’
    96â†’services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/
    97â†’â”œâ”€â”€ config/routing.yaml        # Add Other: [] entry
    98â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prompts/system.jinja2      # Add consent exclusion instruction
    99â†’â”œâ”€â”€ nodes/ground.py            # Rewrite sequential loop to asyncio.gather + semaphore
   100â†’â””â”€â”€ trigger.py                 # Add orphan trace startup cleanup + Issue #8 docs
   101â†’
   102â†’services/protocol-processor-service/tests/
   103â†’â””â”€â”€ test_sentence_extraction.py   # New unit tests for Issue #11
   104â†’
   105â†’libs/shared/tests/              # NOTE: Does not currently exist â€” must create directory
   106â†’â””â”€â”€ test_circuit_breakers.py    # New unit tests for Issue #12
   107â†’
   108â†’services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/tools/
   109â†’â””â”€â”€ tooluniverse_client.py     # Add RxNorm drug class documentation comment
   110â†’```
   111â†’
   112â†’### Pattern 1: Parallel Entity Grounding with asyncio.gather + Semaphore
   113â†’
   114â†’**What:** Convert ground_node's sequential `for` loop to process entities in parallel, using a semaphore to cap concurrency at 4.
   115â†’
   116â†’**When to use:** When the unit of work (entity grounding) is I/O-bound (ToolUniverse HTTP + Vertex AI HTTP) and independent between units.
   117â†’
   118â†’**Current sequential pattern (in ground.py lines 302-387):**
   119â†’```python
   120â†’for idx, entity in enumerate(entity_items, 1):
   121â†’    # ... sequential grounding ...
   122â†’    result = await _ground_entity_with_retry(entity, router, criterion_text)
   123â†’```
   124â†’
   125â†’**New parallel pattern:**
   126â†’```python
   127â†’import asyncio
   128â†’
   129â†’_GROUNDING_SEMAPHORE = asyncio.Semaphore(4)  # module-level, created once
   130â†’
   131â†’async def _ground_entity_parallel(entity, router, criterion_text, entity_num, total):
   132â†’    """Wrapper that acquires semaphore, times execution, grounds entity."""
   133â†’    import time
   134â†’    async with _GROUNDING_SEMAPHORE:
   135â†’        start = time.monotonic()
   136â†’        logger.info(
   137â†’            "Grounding entity %d/%d: '%s' (type=%s)",
   138â†’            entity_num, total, entity.get("text", "")[:50], entity.get("entity_type", "")
   139â†’        )
   140â†’        try:
   141â†’            result = await _ground_entity_with_retry(entity, router, criterion_text)
   142â†’            elapsed = time.monotonic() - start
   143â†’            logger.info(
   144â†’                "Entity '%s' grounded in %.1fs: code=%s, conf=%.2f",
   145â†’                entity.get("text", "")[:50], elapsed, result.selected_code, result.confidence
   146â†’            )
   147â†’            return result, None  # (result, error)
   148â†’        except Exception as e:
   149â†’            elapsed = time.monotonic() - start
   150â†’            logger.error(
   151â†’                "Entity '%s' failed in %.1fs: %s",
   152â†’                entity.get("text", "")[:50], elapsed, e
   153â†’            )
   154â†’            return None, str(e)  # (result, error)
   155â†’
   156â†’# In ground_node, replace the sequential for loop:
   157â†’tasks = [
   158â†’    _ground_entity_parallel(entity, router, criterion_text, idx, len(entity_items))
   159â†’    for idx, entity in enumerate(entity_items, 1)
   160â†’    ...
   161â†’]
   162â†’outcomes = await asyncio.gather(*tasks, return_exceptions=False)  # errors handled in wrapper
   163â†’```
   164â†’
   165â†’**Key design decisions:**
   166â†’- `return_exceptions=False` is safe because errors are caught inside the wrapper
   167â†’- Semaphore is acquired/released per entity. Tenacity retries happen while holding the semaphore (simpler â€” release/reacquire would require refactoring tenacity integration)
   168â†’- Failed entity returns `(None, error_str)` tuple â€” the outer loop converts None to expert_review result, adds error to accumulated_errors, and continues
   169â†’- Per-entity timing is logged at INFO level (start message + end message with elapsed)
   170â†’
   171â†’**Warning:** `asyncio.Semaphore` is NOT thread-safe across different event loops. Since `ground_node` is called within `asyncio.run()` (same event loop per pipeline run), this is safe. Do NOT create the semaphore at module level if it will be shared across multiple asyncio.run() calls â€” create it inside `ground_node` or at the start of each pipeline run.
   172â†’
   173â†’**CRITICAL:** Create the Semaphore inside `ground_node` at the top of the function call, not at module level. `asyncio.Semaphore` belongs to the event loop that creates it â€” creating at module level and using it across multiple `asyncio.run()` calls will raise "got Future attached to a different loop".
   174â†’
   175â†’```python
   176â†’async def ground_node(state: PipelineState) -> dict[str, Any]:
   177â†’    ...
   178â†’    semaphore = asyncio.Semaphore(4)  # Create fresh per pipeline run
   179â†’```
   180â†’
   181â†’### Pattern 2: MedGemma Batch Prompt Structure
   182â†’
   183â†’**What:** Group entities into batches of 4, send all 4 entities in a single MedGemma prompt, parse structured output per entity.
   184â†’
   185â†’**Recommendation (Claude's Discretion):** The existing `medgemma_decide` function in `medgemma_decider.py` calls MedGemma once per entity. For Phase 44's parallelization goal (4 concurrent), the simplest path is **parallel individual calls** (Pattern 1 above) rather than true batching. The semaphore approach already achieves 4x parallelization without needing to rewrite the MedGemma prompt structure.
   186â†’
   187â†’**If true batching is needed** (to reduce token overhead), the batch prompt would:
   188â†’```
   189â†’For each of these 4 entities, select the best terminology match:
   190â†’
   191â†’Entity 1: "{entity_text_1}" (type: {entity_type_1})
   192â†’Candidates: [...]
   193â†’
   194â†’Entity 2: "{entity_text_2}" (type: {entity_type_2})
   195â†’Candidates: [...]
   196â†’...
   197â†’
   198â†’Return a JSON array with one result per entity.
   199â†’```
   200â†’This requires parsing a list-of-results response and attributing results back to entities by index. Given the existing single-entity decision logic in `medgemma_decider.py`, true batching is a larger refactor. The parallel-individual-calls approach (Pattern 1) is lower risk for Phase 44.
   201â†’
   202â†’### Pattern 3: MLflow Orphan Trace Cleanup on Startup
   203â†’
   204â†’**What:** On service start (trigger.py is imported and the graph is first constructed), find IN_PROGRESS MLflow traces older than 1 hour and force-close them as ERROR.
   205â†’
   206â†’**Placement recommendation (Claude's Discretion):** Place in `trigger.py` as a module-level call in an `_cleanup_orphan_traces()` function invoked when the module is first imported. This runs exactly once per process start without requiring Docker entrypoint changes.
   207â†’
   208â†’```python
   209â†’def _cleanup_orphan_traces() -> None:
   210â†’    """Find IN_PROGRESS MLflow traces older than 1 hour and close as ERROR.
   211â†’
   212â†’    Runs once at module import (service startup). Idempotent â€” safe to call
   213â†’    multiple times. Only closes traces older than 1 hour to avoid closing
   214â†’    currently-running pipelines.
   215â†’    """
   216â†’    import time
   217â†’    tracking_uri = os.getenv("MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI")
   218â†’    if not tracking_uri:
   219â†’        return
   220â†’    try:
   221â†’        import mlflow
   222â†’        client = mlflow.MlflowClient()
   223â†’        cutoff_ms = int((time.time() - 3600) * 1000)  # 1 hour ago in milliseconds
   224â†’        # MLflow search_traces with filter for IN_PROGRESS status
   225â†’        # Note: MLflow 3.x search_traces API â€” verify exact filter syntax
   226â†’        traces = client.search_traces(
   227â†’            filter_string="status = 'IN_PROGRESS'",
   228â†’            max_results=50,
   229â†’        )
   230â†’        closed = 0
   231â†’        for trace in traces:
   232â†’            if trace.info.timestamp_ms < cutoff_ms:
   233â†’                try:
   234â†’                    client.end_trace(trace.info.trace_id, status="ERROR")
   235â†’                    closed += 1
   236â†’                except Exception:
   237â†’                    pass  # Trace may have already closed
   238â†’        if closed:
   239â†’            logger.info("Startup orphan cleanup: closed %d stale IN_PROGRESS traces", closed)
   240â†’    except Exception:
   241â†’        logger.debug("Orphan trace cleanup failed (non-fatal)", exc_info=True)
   242â†’
   243â†’# Call at module level:
   244â†’_cleanup_orphan_traces()
   245â†’```
   246â†’
   247â†’**IMPORTANT:** Verify the MLflow 3.x `search_traces` API filter syntax before implementing. The filter string `"status = 'IN_PROGRESS'"` is a guess based on MLflow SQL-like filter syntax. Check MLflow 3.8+ docs for correct syntax.
   248â†’
   249â†’### Pattern 4: Tests for libs/shared
   250â†’
   251â†’The shared lib (`libs/shared`) does NOT currently have a `tests/` directory. The plan proposes creating `libs/shared/tests/test_circuit_breakers.py`. Before doing so:
   252â†’
   253â†’1. The `libs/shared/pyproject.toml` has `testpaths = ["tests"]` already configured â€” just create the directory and the test file.
   254â†’2. The `addopts` includes `--cov=shared` â€” the coverage plugin is configured.
   255â†’3. No `conftest.py` is needed for the circuit breaker tests since `shared.resilience` has no DB or env dependencies.
   256â†’
   257â†’**Running shared tests:**
   258â†’```bash
   259â†’cd libs/shared && uv run pytest tests/test_circuit_breakers.py -v
   260â†’```
   261â†’
   262â†’**Running protocol-processor tests:**
   263â†’```bash
   264â†’cd services/protocol-processor-service && uv run pytest tests/test_sentence_extraction.py -v
   265â†’```
   266â†’
   267â†’### Anti-Patterns to Avoid
   268â†’
   269â†’- **Creating asyncio.Semaphore at module level:** Semaphore belongs to the event loop that creates it. `asyncio.run()` creates a NEW event loop each call â€” a module-level Semaphore from a previous event loop will raise "got Future attached to a different loop". Create inside the async function.
   270â†’- **Using `gather(return_exceptions=True)` without checking results:** If `return_exceptions=True`, exceptions appear as values in the result list â€” easy to miss. The tuple pattern `(result, error)` from the wrapper is cleaner.
   271â†’- **Modifying `_PREAMBLE_PATTERN` or `_extract_term_from_sentence` logic** for the unit tests: The tests must verify existing behavior, not new behavior. Read the existing implementation carefully before writing tests.
   272â†’- **Assuming Demographic is "explicitly skipped"** in routing.yaml: Reading the current routing.yaml shows `Demographic: [umls, snomed]` â€” it is NOT skipped. The `test_terminology_router.py` test `test_demographic_returns_empty_list` is WRONG in the existing plan (it asserts `apis == []` but the actual routing has umls and snomed). Do not replicate this error in new tests.
   273â†’
   274â†’## Don't Hand-Roll
   275â†’
   276â†’| Problem | Don't Build | Use Instead | Why |
   277â†’|---------|-------------|-------------|-----|
   278â†’| Concurrency limiting | Custom queue/worker pool | asyncio.Semaphore + asyncio.gather | Semaphore is the standard asyncio primitive â€” zero boilerplate |
   279â†’| Circuit breaker behavior testing | Mock the breaker state | Create a fresh `pybreaker.CircuitBreaker(fail_max=N)` in test | pybreaker supports programmatic instantiation â€” just create a test-only breaker |
   280â†’| Retry testing | Time-based wait | pybreaker's `state` inspection | Check `test_breaker.current_state` after failures |
   281â†’
   282â†’**Key insight:** The test for circuit breakers should use a fresh `pybreaker.CircuitBreaker` with short timeouts, not mock the existing `tu_breaker` or `gemini_breaker` singletons (which have shared state between test runs).
   283â†’
   284â†’## Common Pitfalls
   285â†’
   286â†’### Pitfall 1: criteria_text is in TWO different contexts in quality_eval.py
   287â†’
   288â†’**What goes wrong:** The bug has three locations (lines 391, 460, 653), but line 653 uses `.get("criteria_text", "")` (with default `""`) while lines 391 and 460 use `.get("criteria_text") or ""`. All three are bugs. A global search-and-replace of `"criteria_text"` â†’ `"text"` would catch all three, but `criterion.get("text")` might conflict with entity dict `.get("text")` lookups in the same file.
   289â†’
   290â†’**Why it happens:** The API response returns `CriterionResponse` objects serialized to JSON â€” the field is `text` (from `ExtractedCriterion.text`). The quality_eval.py code was written with `criteria_text` which does not exist in the schema.
   291â†’
   292â†’**How to avoid:** After the fix, run `grep -n "criteria_text" scripts/quality_eval.py` â€” must return zero results. Also check that `criterion.get("text")` is correct by verifying against `ExtractedCriterion` schema (confirmed: field is `text: str`).
   293â†’
   294â†’**Warning signs:** The API returns empty string criterion text in quality report sections even when protocols have criteria.
   295â†’
   296â†’### Pitfall 2: Demographic routing in routing.yaml is NOT skip: true
   297â†’
   298â†’**What goes wrong:** The existing test in `test_terminology_router.py` has `test_demographic_returns_empty_list` asserting `apis == []`. But reading routing.yaml confirms `Demographic: [umls, snomed]` â€” so this existing test is WRONG or the routing.yaml was changed. Any new tests that assert Demographic behavior must check the actual current routing.yaml first.
   299â†’
   300â†’**Why it happens:** The routing.yaml has a comment noting "Demographic entities are NOT skipped" â€” the test was likely written before this decision or tests a different routing config.
   301â†’
   302â†’**How to avoid:** Before writing any test that asserts expected routing behavior, read routing.yaml. For `test_sentence_extraction.py`, this is not relevant. For circuit breaker tests, use fresh PyBreaker instances.
   303â†’
   304â†’### Pitfall 3: asyncio.Semaphore event loop binding
   305â†’
   306â†’**What goes wrong:** `asyncio.Semaphore(4)` created outside an event loop (e.g., at module import time) will be bound to a specific event loop. When `asyncio.run()` is called (which creates a NEW event loop), using the old semaphore raises `RuntimeError: got Future <Future pending> attached to a different loop`.
   307â†’
   308â†’**Why it happens:** Python's asyncio primitives (Semaphore, Lock, Event) are bound to the running event loop at creation time. `asyncio.run()` creates a fresh event loop each invocation.
   309â†’
   310â†’**How to avoid:** Create the Semaphore inside the `async def ground_node()` function, not at module level. This ensures each pipeline run gets a fresh semaphore in the correct event loop.
   311â†’
   312â†’**Warning signs:** `RuntimeError: got Future attached to a different loop` in logs during grounding.
   313â†’
   314â†’### Pitfall 4: MLflow search_traces API syntax
   315â†’
   316â†’**What goes wrong:** MLflow's `client.search_traces()` or equivalent API for finding IN_PROGRESS traces may have different filter syntax or method names in MLflow 3.8+. Using incorrect syntax silently returns empty results (no orphans cleaned up) or raises an exception.
   317â†’
   318â†’**Why it happens:** MLflow's Python client API has evolved across versions. The `search_traces` method and its filter syntax need to be verified against the actual installed version (mlflow>=3.8.1).
   319â†’
   320â†’**How to avoid:** The orphan cleanup function should be wrapped in a broad `try/except Exception` so that failures are logged but do not crash the service. Verify the actual API by checking MLflow 3.x documentation or the installed package's source.
   321â†’
   322â†’**Warning signs:** Service fails to start; or startup log never shows "closed N stale IN_PROGRESS traces" even when orphans exist.
   323â†’
   324â†’### Pitfall 5: 'Other' routing â€” empty list vs skip: true syntax
   325â†’
   326â†’**What goes wrong:** The TerminologyRouter handles two forms of "skip" in routing.yaml:
   327â†’1. `Consent: {skip: true}` â€” explicit skip dict
   328â†’2. `Other: []` â€” empty list (proposed for Issue #6)
   329â†’
   330â†’Reading `get_apis_for_entity()` in `terminology_router.py`: when `rule` is an empty list `[]`, `isinstance(rule, list)` is True and it returns `[]`. So `Other: []` works correctly without any code change. However, the existing warning log `"Unknown entity type '%s' â€” not in routing config"` will no longer fire for `Other` â€” it will instead silently return `[]` with the INFO-level "explicitly skipped" log path NOT triggering (that only fires for `{skip: true}` dicts).
   331â†’
   332â†’**How to avoid:** Add a YAML comment to clarify that `Other: []` means "no APIs configured" (not an explicit skip), and that the `[]` form is distinct from `{skip: true}`. The behavior is correct, but the log output will be different â€” verify this is acceptable.
   333â†’
   334â†’### Pitfall 6: test_sentence_extraction.py â€” the `too_short` logic
   335â†’
   336â†’**What goes wrong:** The function `_extract_term_from_sentence` uses `too_short = (word_count < 4 OR len < 40)`. This means a 3-word query OR a query under 40 characters bypasses sentence extraction even if one condition is long. Tests for "short query unchanged" must use inputs that satisfy BOTH conditions (less than 4 words AND less than 40 chars), or only one.
   337â†’
   338â†’**Actual code (tooluniverse_client.py line 95-98):**
   339â†’```python
   340â†’too_short = (
   341â†’    word_count < _SENTENCE_WORD_THRESHOLD  # < 4 words
   342â†’    or len(stripped) < _SENTENCE_CHAR_THRESHOLD  # < 40 chars
   343â†’)
   344â†’if too_short:
   345â†’    return stripped
   346â†’```
   347â†’
   348â†’**How to avoid:** Test inputs carefully:
   349â†’- `"eGFR"` â€” 1 word, 4 chars â†’ too_short=True (both) â†’ returns unchanged âœ“
   350â†’- `"ACE inhibitor"` â€” 2 words, 13 chars â†’ too_short=True (both) â†’ returns unchanged âœ“
   351â†’- `"The patient must have a diagnosis of myocardial infarction"` â€” 10 words, 59 chars â†’ too_short=False â†’ sentence extraction triggered âœ“
   352â†’- `"osteoarthritis"` â€” 1 word, 14 chars â†’ too_short=True â†’ returns unchanged âœ“
   353â†’
   354â†’The plan's test `test_short_query_unchanged` with `"ACE inhibitor"` (2 words, 13 chars) correctly expects it to pass through unchanged.

   414â†’### Circuit breaker tests â€” fresh PyBreaker instance
   415â†’
   416â†’```python
   417â†’"""Tests for circuit breaker behavior in resilience module."""

   419â†’import pytest
   420â†’
   421â†’from shared.resilience import tu_breaker, gemini_breaker
   422â†’
   423â†’
   424â†’class _SimulatedError(Exception):
   425â†’    pass

   427â†’

   430â†’    assert tu_breaker._fail_max == 10
   431â†’    assert tu_breaker._reset_timeout == 60
   432â†’
   433â†’

   439â†’
   440â†’def test_breaker_opens_after_failures():

   442â†’    test_breaker = pybreaker.CircuitBreaker(fail_max=3, reset_timeout=60, name="test_phase44")
   443â†’
   444â†’    @test_breaker
   445â†’    def failing_call():
   446â†’        raise _SimulatedError("boom")
   447â†’

   450â†’            failing_call()
   451â†’
   452â†’    with pytest.raises(pybreaker.CircuitBreakerError):
   453â†’        failing_call()

   456â†’Note: Use unique `name=` per test breaker to avoid shared state between tests.

   505â†’## State of the Art
   506â†’
   507â†’| Old Approach | Current Approach | When Changed | Impact |
   508â†’|--------------|------------------|--------------|--------|
   509â†’| Sequential entity grounding | Parallel with asyncio.gather + semaphore | Phase 44 | ~4x grounding speedup (10 min â†’ ~2-3 min) |
   510â†’| No 'Other' routing entry (warning logs) | Explicit `Other: []` in routing.yaml | Phase 44 | Cleaner logs, documented behavior |
   511â†’| Consent criteria extracted by LLM | LLM instructed to exclude consent in system prompt | Phase 44 | Fewer spurious criteria in results |
   512â†’| MLflow orphan traces require manual cleanup | Automated startup cleanup | Phase 44 | Idempotent cleanup on every service start |

   517â†’- The existing plan treats orphan trace cleanup as documentation-only (Task 5) â€” CONTEXT.md requires automated startup cleanup code.
   518â†’
   519â†’## Open Questions
   520â†’
   521â†’1. **MLflow search_traces API for IN_PROGRESS traces**
   522â†’   - What we know: `mlflow.MlflowClient()` has `end_trace(trace_id, status=...)` confirmed in trigger.py
   523â†’   - What's unclear: The exact method name and filter syntax for finding IN_PROGRESS traces in MLflow 3.8+. `client.search_traces()` may require different filter syntax or may not exist â€” MLflow 3.x traces API differs from the runs API.
   524â†’   - Recommendation: Implement orphan cleanup with a broad try/except so startup never fails even if the MLflow API call fails. Check official MLflow 3.x changelog for `search_traces` method signature.
   525â†’
   526â†’2. **Whether `_extract_term_from_sentence` is importable from the test context**
   527â†’   - What we know: It is a module-level function in `tooluniverse_client.py`, prefixed with `_` (private by convention but importable)
   528â†’   - What's unclear: Whether the `_` prefix will cause any import issues in practice (it won't in Python â€” single underscore is a convention only)
   529â†’   - Recommendation: Import as `from protocol_processor.tools.tooluniverse_client import _extract_term_from_sentence` â€” the conftest.py sets DATABASE_URL, but ToolUniverse init happens lazily (only on first call to `_get_tu()`), so importing the module should not trigger ToolUniverse initialization.
   530â†’
   531â†’3. **FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 traceability**
   532â†’   - What we know: REQUIREMENTS.md shows FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 as "Pending" assigned to Phase 44
   533â†’   - What's unclear: Were these actually implemented in Phase 43? The REQUIREMENTS.md traceability table says Phase 44 but the 44-01-PLAN.md's `must_haves.truths` includes assertions about ProtocolList dedup and Retry/Archive buttons being visible.
   534â†’   - Recommendation: Check Phase 43 commits and the ProtocolList.tsx implementation to determine if FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 are already implemented (in which case, the plan just needs to update traceability) or still need implementation.
   535â†’
   536â†’## Sources
   537â†’
   538â†’### Primary (HIGH confidence)
   539â†’
   540â†’- Direct code reading: `scripts/quality_eval.py` â€” confirmed `criteria_text` bug at lines 391, 460, 653
   541â†’- Direct code reading: `services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/schemas/extraction.py` â€” confirmed field name is `text: str` in `ExtractedCriterion`
   542â†’- Direct code reading: `services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/config/routing.yaml` â€” confirmed no `Other` entry, confirmed `Demographic: [umls, snomed]` (NOT skipped), confirmed `Consent: {skip: true}`
   543â†’- Direct code reading: `services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` â€” confirmed sequential loop ready for parallelization
   544â†’- Direct code reading: `services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/tools/tooluniverse_client.py` â€” confirmed `_extract_term_from_sentence` function logic and `_PREAMBLE_PATTERN`
   545â†’- Direct code reading: `libs/shared/src/shared/resilience.py` â€” confirmed `tu_breaker._fail_max=10`, `gemini_breaker._fail_max=3`, both `reset_timeout=60`
   546â†’- Direct code reading: `.planning/REQUIREMENTS.md` â€” confirmed CLEAN-01 through CLEAN-05 are Complete/Phase 40; confirmed FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 are Pending/Phase 44
   547â†’- Direct code reading: `services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/trigger.py` â€” confirmed existing orphan trace handling pattern with `mlflow.MlflowClient().end_trace()`
   548â†’- Direct code reading: `instructions/E2E-TEST-REPORT-2026-02-18-phase42-issues.json` â€” confirmed all 12 issue descriptions and suggested solutions
   549â†’- Direct code reading: `libs/shared/pyproject.toml` â€” confirmed `testpaths = ["tests"]` is configured (no tests dir yet, must create)
   550â†’- Direct code reading: `services/protocol-processor-service/pyproject.toml` â€” confirmed pytest config, `asyncio_mode = "auto"`, DATABASE_URL conftest needed
   551â†’- Direct code reading: `services/protocol-processor-service/tests/conftest.py` â€” confirmed DATABASE_URL env var is set by conftest
   552â†’
   553â†’### Secondary (MEDIUM confidence)
   554â†’
   555â†’- asyncio.Semaphore event loop binding behavior â€” documented Python asyncio behavior, well-known pitfall
   556â†’- pybreaker fresh instance approach for testing â€” based on reading pybreaker API from resilience.py usage
   557â†’
   558â†’### Tertiary (LOW confidence)
   559â†’
   560â†’- MLflow 3.8+ `search_traces` API filter syntax for IN_PROGRESS â€” not verified against official docs; needs validation before implementation
   561â†’
   562â†’## Metadata
   563â†’
   564â†’**Confidence breakdown:**
   565â†’- Bug fix (criteria_text): HIGH â€” bug confirmed by reading both schema and buggy code
   566â†’- Unit tests (Issues #11, #12): HIGH â€” existing test patterns in test_terminology_router.py are clear
   567â†’- YAML config changes (Issues #6, #9): HIGH â€” TerminologyRouter behavior confirmed by reading code
   568â†’- System prompt change (Issue #5): HIGH â€” simple text addition to existing jinja2 file
   569â†’- Grounding parallelization (Issue #7): MEDIUM â€” asyncio patterns are well-understood, but Semaphore event loop binding requires care
   570â†’- Orphan trace cleanup (Issue #4): MEDIUM â€” MLflow client API usage confirmed, but search_traces filter syntax needs verification
   571â†’- Traceability verification (CLEAN-0x, FIX-B6/B8): HIGH â€” REQUIREMENTS.md confirms current state
   572â†’

   574â†’**Valid until:** 2026-03-18 (stable codebase, no fast-moving external dependencies for core fixes)
   575â†’

content.content:
- DO NOT DEFER â€” implement in this phase
- Concurrency: 4 concurrent entity groundings via asyncio.gather with semaphore
- Both ToolUniverse lookups AND MedGemma calls run concurrently
- Batching: group entities into batches of 4 for MedGemma calls (4 entities per prompt, run batches concurrently)
- Error isolation: if one entity fails in a parallel batch, others continue â€” failed entity gets expert_review routing
- Per-entity timing in logs (start/end/duration) for benchmarking
- Tenacity retry for retryable errors within parallel grounding

### Orphan Trace Cleanup (Issue #4)
- Automated startup cleanup script (not doc-only)
--
- Exact placement of orphan trace cleanup (trigger.py vs entrypoint)
- MLflow ContextVar documentation format and placement (Issue #8)
- MedGemma batch prompt structure for multi-entity calls

</decisions>

<specifics>
## Specific Ideas

- Grounding parallelization should target ~2-3 min total grounding time (down from ~10 min sequential)
- Batch-of-4 MedGemma calls should include all entity context in a single prompt, with structured output for each entity
- Orphan cleanup should be idempotent (safe to run multiple times)

</specifics>

content.content:
13:<decisions>
14:## Implementation Decisions
15:
16:### No Playwright Tests
17:- Playwright tests are removed from Phase 44 scope entirely
18:- Phase 43 UI verification will be done through other means (manual or future phase)
19:
20:### E2E Issue Triage
21:- **Already fixed (prior phases):** Issues #1 (local:// URI), #2 (MLflow timeout), #3 (NoneType after timeout), #10 (trace duration mismatch)
22:- **In-scope for Phase 44:** Issues #4 (orphan traces â€” startup cleanup), #5 (consent extraction), #6 ('Other' routing), #7 (grounding parallelization), #9 (RxNorm docs), #11 (sentence extraction test), #12 (circuit breaker test)
23:- **Documentation-only:** Issue #8 (MLflow ContextVar async boundary â€” document limitation)
24:- Plan should only mention what actually needs fixing, not a full status table of all 12 issues
25:
26:### Issue #6: 'Other' Entity Type Routing
27:- Add explicit `Other: []` entry in routing.yaml with a comment that these are non-groundable catch-all entities
28:- Config-driven approach (YAML), not code change in TerminologyRouter
29:
30:### Grounding Parallelization (Issue #7)
31:- DO NOT DEFER â€” implement in this phase
32:- Concurrency: 4 concurrent entity groundings via asyncio.gather with semaphore
33:- Both ToolUniverse lookups AND MedGemma calls run concurrently
34:- Batching: group entities into batches of 4 for MedGemma calls (4 entities per prompt, run batches concurrently)
35:- Error isolation: if one entity fails in a parallel batch, others continue â€” failed entity gets expert_review routing
36:- Per-entity timing in logs (start/end/duration) for benchmarking
37:- Tenacity retry for retryable errors within parallel grounding
38:
39:### Orphan Trace Cleanup (Issue #4)
40:- Automated startup cleanup script (not doc-only)
41:- On service start, find MLflow traces IN_PROGRESS older than 1 hour and close them as ERROR
42:- Placement: Claude's discretion (trigger.py startup or Docker entrypoint)
43:
44:### Claude's Discretion
45:- Whether tenacity retries hold the semaphore slot or release/reacquire (implementation complexity tradeoff)
46:- Exact placement of orphan trace cleanup (trigger.py vs entrypoint)
47:- MLflow ContextVar documentation format and placement (Issue #8)
48:- MedGemma batch prompt structure for multi-entity calls
49:
50:</decisions>

- MedGemma batch prompt structure for multi-entity calls

### Deferred Ideas (OUT OF SCOPE)

None â€” discussion stayed within phase scope
</user_constraints>

<phase_requirements>
## Phase Requirements

| ID | Description | Research Support |
--
The grounding parallelization (Issue #7) is the highest-complexity change: converting the sequential `for` loop in `ground_node` to use `asyncio.gather` with a semaphore. The existing architecture in `ground.py` is a single async function with a sequential loop â€” this is ready to be parallelized without any structural changes needed beyond the loop itself. The MedGemma batching decision is for Claude's discretion â€” the existing `medgemma_decider.py` calls one entity at a time, and the batch prompt structure needs to be defined.

CLEAN-01 through CLEAN-05 are already confirmed Complete in REQUIREMENTS.md with Phase 40 assignment, so the traceability verification task is purely a read-and-confirm step (the plan only needs to mark FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 as Complete for Phase 43, since those were implemented in Phase 43 per the dashboard UX work).

**Primary recommendation:** Fix the `criteria_text` â†’ `text` rename first (lowest risk, highest value), then add the `Other: []` YAML entry and consent prompt instruction, then implement the unit tests, then tackle grounding parallelization last (highest complexity, most testing needed).

## Standard Stack

### Core

| Library | Version | Purpose | Why Standard |
--
**Recommendation (Claude's Discretion):** The existing `medgemma_decide` function in `medgemma_decider.py` calls MedGemma once per entity. For Phase 44's parallelization goal (4 concurrent), the simplest path is **parallel individual calls** (Pattern 1 above) rather than true batching. The semaphore approach already achieves 4x parallelization without needing to rewrite the MedGemma prompt structure.

**If true batching is needed** (to reduce token overhead), the batch prompt would:
```
For each of these 4 entities, select the best terminology match:

Entity 1: "{entity_text_1}" (type: {entity_type_1})
Candidates: [...]

Entity 2: "{entity_text_2}" (type: {entity_type_2})
Candidates: [...]
...

--
This requires parsing a list-of-results response and attributing results back to entities by index. Given the existing single-entity decision logic in `medgemma_decider.py`, true batching is a larger refactor. The parallel-individual-calls approach (Pattern 1) is lower risk for Phase 44.

**Dimension 7 â€” Context Compliance (critical finding):**

The CONTEXT.md Locked Decisions section states: "Batching: group entities into batches of 4 for MedGemma calls (4 entities per prompt, run batches concurrently)" â€” this is in the **Decisions** block (locked). Plan 44-03 implements parallel individual calls (not true MedGemma prompt batching). However, the same CONTEXT.md then lists "MedGemma batch prompt structure for multi-entity calls" under **Claude's Discretion**. This creates an internal tension in CONTEXT.md itself â€” the research resolved it in favor of discretion (individual calls are acceptable), and the plan follows that resolution. This needs to be flagged as a warning.

The other locked decision â€” "No Playwright Tests" â€” is correctly honored (zero Playwright references in any plan).

### Dimension 6: Verification Derivation â€” PASSED

`must_haves.truths` across all plans are user/behavior-observable:
- "Quality report LLM assessment section shows real criterion text (not empty strings)" â€” observable output
- "Entity grounding runs up to 4 entities concurrently via asyncio.gather with semaphore" â€” behavioral truth
- "Orphan MLflow traces older than 1 hour are automatically closed as ERROR on service startup" â€” behavioral truth

Artifacts map to truths. Key links connect dependent artifacts. No implementation-focused truths detected.

---

### Dimension 7: Context Compliance â€” 2 WARNINGS

**Warning 1: MedGemma Batching â€” Ambiguous Locked vs Discretion Decision**

```yaml
issue:
  plan: "44-03"
  dimension: context_compliance
  severity: warning
  description: >
    CONTEXT.md Decisions section (locked) states "Batching: group entities into batches of 4
    for MedGemma calls (4 entities per prompt, run batches concurrently)". Plan 44-03 implements

  user_decision: "Batching: group entities into batches of 4 for MedGemma calls (4 entities per prompt, run batches concurrently) [Decisions section, locked]"
  plan_action: "Creates _ground_entity_parallel wrapper that calls _ground_entity_with_retry once per entity â€” parallel individual calls, not 4-entity prompts"
  fix_hint: >
    If the user intended MedGemma prompt batching as a hard requirement, 44-03 Task 1 needs
    a medgemma_decider.py change to accept 4 entities per call and parse list-structured output.
    If parallel individual calls are acceptable (which RESEARCH.md argues), the CONTEXT.md
    Decisions wording should be clarified to avoid this ambiguity. Given the Discretion clause
    covers the prompt structure, execution can proceed as planned â€” but flag for user confirmation

```

**Warning 2: ROADMAP Success Criteria Items 3 and 4 Not Satisfied by Plans**

issue:

  dimension: context_compliance

  roadmap_criteria: "Items 3 and 4 in Phase 44 success criteria specify Playwright confirmation"
  plan_action: "44-01 Task 1 updates REQUIREMENTS.md to mark FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 Complete based on Phase 43 commits â€” no Playwright test"
  fix_hint: >
    Either update ROADMAP.md Phase 44 success criteria items 3 and 4 to remove Playwright
    references (replacing with "Phase 43 commits confirmed" or "manual verification"), or
    accept that Phase 44 will close FIX-B6 and FIX-B8 via traceability update without

    the ROADMAP just needs to catch up.
```

### Info

```yaml
issue:
  plan: "44-02"
  dimension: verification_derivation
  severity: info
  description: >
    Plan 44-02 lists QUAL-07, BUG-01, BUG-03 in its requirements frontmatter, but its tasks

---

### Recommendation

0 blockers â€” plans are executionally sound and can proceed. Both warnings are real tensions worth reviewing before execution, but neither prevents the plans from achieving the phase goal.

**Most important question before execution:** Does the user want true MedGemma prompt batching (4 entities in one prompt, parse structured list output) or is parallel individual calls acceptable? The CONTEXT.md wording implies batching, but the Discretion clause and RESEARCH.md both support individual calls as equivalent for the speedup goal. If batching is truly required, 44-03 needs a `medgemma_decider.py` change â€” which is currently absent from `files_modified`.

Plans verified. If the MedGemma batching ambiguity is resolved in favor of individual parallel calls (as RESEARCH.md recommends), run `/gsd:execute-phase 44` to proceed.

   132â†’"""Tests for circuit breaker behavior in resilience module."""
   133â†’import pybreaker
   134â†’import pytest
   135â†’
   136â†’from shared.resilience import tu_breaker, gemini_breaker

   143â†’def test_tu_breaker_config():

   146â†’    assert tu_breaker._reset_timeout == 60
   147â†’
   148â†’
   149â†’def test_gemini_breaker_config():

   151â†’    assert gemini_breaker._fail_max == 3
   152â†’    assert gemini_breaker._reset_timeout == 60
   153â†’
   154â†’
   155â†’def test_breaker_opens_after_failures():
   156â†’    """A fresh breaker opens after fail_max consecutive failures."""
   157â†’    test_breaker = pybreaker.CircuitBreaker(
   158â†’        fail_max=3, reset_timeout=60, name="test_phase44_open"
   159â†’    )
   160â†’
   161â†’    @test_breaker
   162â†’    def failing_call():
   163â†’        raise _SimulatedError("boom")
   164â†’
   165â†’    # Trip the breaker with fail_max failures
   166â†’    for _ in range(3):
   167â†’        with pytest.raises(_SimulatedError):
   168â†’            failing_call()
   169â†’
   170â†’    # Next call should be rejected by the open breaker
   171â†’    with pytest.raises(pybreaker.CircuitBreakerError):
   172â†’        failing_call()
   173â†’
   174â†’
   175â†’def test_breaker_rejects_during_open():
   176â†’    """Open breaker rejects calls without executing the function."""
   177â†’    call_count = 0
   178â†’    test_breaker = pybreaker.CircuitBreaker(
   179â†’        fail_max=2, reset_timeout=300, name="test_phase44_reject"
   180â†’    )
   181â†’
   182â†’    @test_breaker
   183â†’    def counting_call():
   184â†’        nonlocal call_count
   185â†’        call_count += 1
   186â†’        raise _SimulatedError("boom")
   187â†’
   188â†’    # Trip breaker
   189â†’    for _ in range(2):
   190â†’        with pytest.raises(_SimulatedError):
   191â†’            counting_call()
   192â†’
   193â†’    assert call_count == 2
   194â†’
   195â†’    # Open breaker rejects without calling the function
   196â†’    with pytest.raises(pybreaker.CircuitBreakerError):
   197â†’        counting_call()
   198â†’
   199â†’    assert call_count == 2  # Not incremented â€” function was not called
   200â†’
   201â†’
   202â†’def test_breaker_success_resets_count():
   203â†’    """Successful calls reset the failure count."""
   204â†’    test_breaker = pybreaker.CircuitBreaker(
   205â†’        fail_max=3, reset_timeout=60, name="test_phase44_reset"
   206â†’    )
   207â†’    fail = False
   208â†’
   209â†’    @test_breaker
   210â†’    def maybe_fail():
   211â†’        if fail:
   212â†’            raise _SimulatedError("boom")
   213â†’        return "ok"
   214â†’
   215â†’    # 2 failures (not enough to trip)
   216â†’    fail = True
   217â†’    for _ in range(2):
   218â†’        with pytest.raises(_SimulatedError):
   219â†’            maybe_fail()
   220â†’
   221â†’    # 1 success resets count
   222â†’    fail = False
   223â†’    assert maybe_fail() == "ok"
   224â†’
   225â†’    # 2 more failures â€” still not tripped (count was reset)
   226â†’    fail = True
   227â†’    for _ in range(2):
   228â†’        with pytest.raises(_SimulatedError):
   229â†’            maybe_fail()
   230â†’
   231â†’    # Should still be closed (2 < fail_max=3)
   232â†’    fail = False
   233â†’    assert maybe_fail() == "ok"
   234â†’```

    67â†’  <name>Task 1: Parallelize entity grounding with asyncio.gather and semaphore</name>
    68â†’  <files>services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py</files>
    69â†’  <action>
    70â†’Convert the sequential entity grounding loop in `ground_node` to parallel execution using `asyncio.gather` with a semaphore capped at 4 concurrent entities.
    71â†’
    72â†’**Step 1: Create a parallel wrapper function**
    73â†’
    74â†’Add a new async helper function `_ground_entity_parallel` that:
    75â†’1. Accepts the entity dict, router, criterion_text, entity_num, total count, and the semaphore
    76â†’2. Acquires the semaphore before grounding (controls concurrency to 4)
    77â†’3. Logs per-entity timing at INFO level: start message with entity text/type, end message with elapsed time and result
    78â†’4. Calls the existing `_ground_entity_with_retry` inside the semaphore context
    79â†’5. Returns a `(result, error)` tuple â€” on success `(result, None)`, on exception `(None, str(error))`
    80â†’6. Catches exceptions so that one failed entity does not crash others
    81â†’
    82â†’```python
    83â†’import asyncio
    84â†’import time
    85â†’
    86â†’async def _ground_entity_parallel(
    87â†’    entity: dict,
    88â†’    router,
    89â†’    criterion_text: str,
    90â†’    entity_num: int,
    91â†’    total: int,
    92â†’    semaphore: asyncio.Semaphore,
    93â†’) -> tuple:
    94â†’    """Ground a single entity with concurrency control and timing."""
    95â†’    async with semaphore:
    96â†’        entity_text = entity.get("text", "")[:50]
    97â†’        entity_type = entity.get("entity_type", "")
    98â†’        start = time.monotonic()
    99â†’        logger.info(
   100â†’            "Grounding entity %d/%d: '%s' (type=%s) â€” start",
   101â†’            entity_num, total, entity_text, entity_type,
   102â†’        )
   103â†’        try:
   104â†’            result = await _ground_entity_with_retry(entity, router, criterion_text)
   105â†’            elapsed = time.monotonic() - start
   106â†’            logger.info(
   107â†’                "Entity %d/%d '%s' grounded in %.1fs: code=%s, conf=%.2f",
   108â†’                entity_num, total, entity_text, elapsed,
   109â†’                getattr(result, 'selected_code', 'N/A'),
   110â†’                getattr(result, 'confidence', 0.0),
   111â†’            )
   112â†’            return (result, None)
   113â†’        except Exception as e:
   114â†’            elapsed = time.monotonic() - start
   115â†’            logger.error(
   116â†’                "Entity %d/%d '%s' failed in %.1fs: %s",
   117â†’                entity_num, total, entity_text, elapsed, e,
   118â†’            )
   119â†’            return (None, str(e))
   120â†’```
   121â†’
   122â†’**Step 2: Replace the sequential loop in ground_node**
   123â†’
   124â†’Find the sequential `for idx, entity in enumerate(entity_items, 1):` loop inside `ground_node`. Replace it with:
   125â†’
   126â†’1. Create the semaphore INSIDE `ground_node` (NOT at module level â€” asyncio.Semaphore is bound to the event loop that creates it, and `asyncio.run()` creates a new event loop each call):
   127â†’   ```python
   128â†’   semaphore = asyncio.Semaphore(4)
   129â†’   ```
   130â†’
   131â†’2. Build the list of coroutine tasks:
   132â†’   ```python
   133â†’   tasks = [
   134â†’       _ground_entity_parallel(entity, router, criterion_text, idx, len(entity_items), semaphore)
   135â†’       for idx, entity in enumerate(entity_items, 1)
   136â†’   ]
   137â†’   ```
   138â†’
   139â†’3. Execute all in parallel:
   140â†’   ```python
   141â†’   outcomes = await asyncio.gather(*tasks)
   142â†’   ```
   143â†’
   144â†’4. Process outcomes: iterate over `outcomes` alongside `entity_items`. For each `(result, error)`:
   145â†’   - If `result is not None`: use it as the grounding result (same as the current sequential code does with successful results)
   146â†’   - If `result is None` (error): create an expert_review fallback result and add the error string to `accumulated_errors` (matching current error handling pattern)
   147â†’
   148â†’**CRITICAL design decisions per user's locked decisions:**
   149â†’- Concurrency cap: 4 (via semaphore)
   150â†’- Both ToolUniverse lookups AND MedGemma calls run concurrently (they are called inside `_ground_entity_with_retry` which is called inside the semaphore)
   151â†’- Tenacity retries HOLD the semaphore slot (simpler implementation â€” retries happen inside `async with semaphore`)
   152â†’- Error isolation: `(None, error)` tuple pattern means gather never raises (errors caught in wrapper)
   153â†’- Per-entity timing logged at INFO level
   154â†’
   155â†’**IMPORTANT:** Do NOT change the function signature of `ground_node`. Do NOT change how results are stored â€” only change the iteration pattern from sequential to parallel. The post-loop code that builds the grounded entities list must still work identically.
   156â†’
   157â†’Read ground.py carefully before making changes. Preserve all existing logic for: consent skipping, entity type routing, result accumulation, error tracking, and the final state update.
   158â†’  </action>
   159â†’  <verify>
   160â†’Run: `grep "asyncio.gather" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` â€” must show the gather call.
   161â†’Run: `grep "asyncio.Semaphore" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` â€” must show semaphore creation inside ground_node.
   162â†’Run: `grep "_ground_entity_parallel" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` â€” must show the helper function.
   163â†’Run: `uv run ruff check services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` â€” must pass clean.
   164â†’Run: `uv run mypy services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py --ignore-missing-imports` â€” should pass (or only pre-existing issues).
   165â†’  </verify>
   166â†’  <done>Sequential entity grounding loop replaced with asyncio.gather + Semaphore(4). Per-entity timing logged. Failed entities get expert_review without crashing batch. Tenacity retries hold semaphore slot.</done>
   167â†’</task>
   168â†’
   169â†’<task type="auto">
   170â†’  <name>Task 2: Implement orphan MLflow trace cleanup on startup</name>
   171â†’  <files>services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/trigger.py</files>
   172â†’  <action>
   173â†’Add an automated startup cleanup function that finds IN_PROGRESS MLflow traces older than 1 hour and closes them as ERROR. Per user decision: automated cleanup, not doc-only.
   174â†’
   175â†’**Step 1: Create `_cleanup_orphan_traces()` function**
   176â†’
   177â†’Place it near the top of trigger.py (after imports, before the graph construction code). The function should:
   178â†’
   179â†’1. Check for `MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI` env var â€” if not set, return silently (no MLflow configured)
   180â†’2. Create an `mlflow.MlflowClient()` instance
   181â†’3. Calculate cutoff timestamp: 1 hour ago in milliseconds
   182â†’4. Search for IN_PROGRESS traces using the MLflow client API
   183â†’5. For each trace older than the cutoff, call `client.end_trace(trace_id, status="ERROR")`
   184â†’6. Log the count of closed traces at INFO level
   185â†’7. Wrap everything in broad `try/except Exception` â€” startup must NEVER fail due to cleanup
   186â†’
   187â†’```python
   188â†’def _cleanup_orphan_traces() -> None:
   189â†’    """Close stale IN_PROGRESS MLflow traces from previous crashed runs.
   190â†’
   191â†’    Runs once at module import (service startup). Idempotent â€” safe to
   192â†’    call multiple times. Only closes traces older than 1 hour to avoid
   193â†’    closing currently-running pipelines.
   194â†’    """
   195â†’    import time as _time
   196â†’
   197â†’    tracking_uri = os.getenv("MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI")
   198â†’    if not tracking_uri:
   199â†’        return
   200â†’    try:
   201â†’        import mlflow
   202â†’
   203â†’        client = mlflow.MlflowClient()
   204â†’        cutoff_ms = int((_time.time() - 3600) * 1000)  # 1 hour ago
   205â†’
   206â†’        # MLflow 3.x: search for traces with IN_PROGRESS status
   207â†’        # The exact API may vary â€” try search_traces first, fall back gracefully
   208â†’        try:
   209â†’            traces = client.search_traces(
   210â†’                experiment_ids=["0"],  # Default experiment
   211â†’                filter_string="status = 'IN_PROGRESS'",
   212â†’                max_results=50,
   213â†’            )
   214â†’        except (AttributeError, TypeError):
   215â†’            # search_traces may not exist or have different signature in this MLflow version
   216â†’            logger.debug("MLflow search_traces API not available for orphan cleanup")
   217â†’            return
   218â†’
   219â†’        closed = 0
   220â†’        for trace in traces:
   221â†’            trace_ts = getattr(trace.info, "timestamp_ms", None) or 0
   222â†’            if trace_ts < cutoff_ms:
   223â†’                try:
   224â†’                    client.end_trace(
   225â†’                        request_id=trace.info.request_id,
   226â†’                        status="ERROR",
   227â†’                    )
   228â†’                    closed += 1
   229â†’                except Exception:
   230â†’                    pass  # Trace may have already been closed
   231â†’        if closed:
   232â†’            logger.info(
   233â†’                "Startup orphan cleanup: closed %d stale IN_PROGRESS trace(s)",
   234â†’                closed,
   235â†’            )
   236â†’    except Exception:
   237â†’        logger.debug("Orphan trace cleanup skipped (non-fatal)", exc_info=True)
   238â†’```
   239â†’
   240â†’**Step 2: Call at module level**
   241â†’
   242â†’Add `_cleanup_orphan_traces()` call at module level, after the function definition but before the graph construction. This ensures it runs exactly once when the module is first imported (service startup).
   243â†’
   244â†’```python
   245â†’# Run once at startup to clean up orphaned traces from previous crashes
   246â†’_cleanup_orphan_traces()
   247â†’```
   248â†’
   249â†’**IMPORTANT:**
   250â†’- The function MUST be idempotent (safe to call multiple times)
   251â†’- The function MUST NOT crash the service (broad try/except)
   252â†’- The MLflow `search_traces` API syntax may differ across versions â€” the try/except around it handles this gracefully
   253â†’- Use `request_id` (not `trace_id`) for `end_trace` â€” check the existing usage in trigger.py for the correct parameter name
   254â†’- Check the MLflow client API actually used in trigger.py to match parameter names exactly
   255â†’  </action>
   256â†’  <verify>
   257â†’Run: `grep "_cleanup_orphan_traces" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/trigger.py` â€” must show both the function definition and the module-level call.
   258â†’Run: `grep "Startup orphan cleanup" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/trigger.py` â€” must show the log message.
   259â†’Run: `uv run ruff check services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/trigger.py` â€” must pass clean.
   260â†’  </verify>
   261â†’  <done>Orphan trace cleanup function added to trigger.py. Runs at module import, finds IN_PROGRESS traces older than 1 hour, closes as ERROR. Idempotent and non-fatal.</done>
   262â†’</task>
   263â†’
   264â†’</tasks>
   265â†’
   266â†’<verification>
   267â†’1. `grep "asyncio.gather" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` shows gather call
   268â†’2. `grep "Semaphore(4)" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` shows semaphore inside ground_node
   269â†’3. `grep "_ground_entity_parallel" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` shows helper function
   270â†’4. `grep "_cleanup_orphan_traces" services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/trigger.py` shows function + call
   271â†’5. `uv run ruff check services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/nodes/ground.py` passes
   272â†’6. `uv run ruff check services/protocol-processor-service/src/protocol_processor/trigger.py` passes
   273â†’</verification>
   274â†’
   275â†’<success_criteria>
   276â†’1. Entity grounding uses asyncio.gather with Semaphore(4) for up to 4 concurrent groundings
   277â†’2. Per-entity timing logged at INFO level with entity text, type, elapsed time, and result
   278â†’3. Failed entities get expert_review routing; other entities continue unaffected
   279â†’4. Semaphore created inside ground_node (not at module level) to avoid event loop binding issues
   280â†’5. Orphan trace cleanup runs automatically on service startup
   281â†’6. Cleanup is idempotent and non-fatal (broad try/except)
   282â†’7. All linting passes
   283â†’</success_criteria>
   284â†’
   285â†’<output>
   286â†’After completion, create `.REDACTED.md`
   287â†’</output>
   288â†’
